definitions: put a shirt on someone or oneself as clothing
avoid or shirk a duty or responsibility through clever evasion
examples: The mother carefully shirted her toddler before breakfast
He shirted himself quickly for the morning meeting
Politicians often try to shirt blame onto their opponents
She always shirts her responsibilities when things get difficult

definitions: expel feces from the body through the bowels
tell lies or deliberately mislead someone with false information
examples: The dog needs to shit outside in the yard
He rushed to the bathroom needing to shit urgently
Don't shit me about where you were last night
She's been shitting everyone about her fake credentials

definitions: shake slightly and uncontrollably as a result of being cold
tremble with fear excitement or another strong emotion
break into small pieces or splinters especially from impact
examples: She began to shiver in the freezing winter wind
The wet dog shivered after coming out of the lake
He shivered with anticipation before opening the letter
The audience shivered at the horror movie's climax
The mirror shivered into a thousand pieces when dropped
The ancient timber shivered under the heavy blow

definitions: of water become shallow gradually especially near shore
of fish or people come together in a large group
examples: The water shoals rapidly as you approach the beach
The river shoals dangerously near the old bridge
Sardines shoal together for protection from predators
Tourists tend to shoal around popular landmarks

definitions: cause someone to feel surprised and upset by something unexpected
collide with something violently or strike with physical force
subject to an electric shock for medical or punitive purposes
examples: The news of his sudden death shocked the entire community
Her rude behavior shocked everyone at the formal dinner
The earthquake shocked buildings throughout the downtown area
The collision shocked both vehicles off the road
The doctors shocked his heart back into normal rhythm
The fence is designed to shock intruders with electricity

definitions: put shoes on someone's feet or one's own feet
fit a horse with horseshoes for protection and traction
examples: She carefully shoed her children before they went outside
He quickly shoed himself for the important meeting
The blacksmith will shoe your horse this afternoon
They need to shoe all the horses before winter

definitions: make a person or animal go away by waving or making sounds
examples: She shooed the chickens away from her vegetable garden
The security guard shooed loiterers from the store entrance
He tried to shoo the flies from his sandwich
The farmer shooed birds from his newly planted crops

definitions: discharge a bullet or arrow from a weapon at target
take photographs or make a film or video recording
move suddenly and rapidly in a particular direction
of a plant send out buds or new growth rapidly
examples: The hunter shot a deer with his rifle yesterday
Police officers shot at the fleeing suspect's vehicle
They will shoot the wedding ceremony tomorrow afternoon
The director shot the entire movie in three months
The car shot forward when the light turned green
Pain shot through her injured ankle suddenly
Bamboo shoots up several feet in just one season
New leaves shot from the pruned rose bush

definitions: visit stores to buy goods or look at merchandise
inform on someone to the authorities especially to police
examples: She shops for groceries every Saturday morning downtown
They love to shop at the new mall together
He threatened to shop his accomplices to the police
The criminal was shopped by his own partner

definitions: support or hold up something with props or beams to prevent collapse
examples: Workers shored up the old building with steel beams
They need to shore the tunnel walls before excavation
The government shored up the failing banks with loans
She tried to shore up her failing argument with statistics

definitions: make or become shorter in physical length or distance
reduce the duration or time span of an activity or event
examples: The tailor shortened her dress by three inches yesterday
Cold weather shortens the lifespan of car batteries
They decided to shorten the meeting to thirty minutes
Bad weather shortened our vacation by two days

definitions: put someone or something on a final list of candidates for selection
examples: The committee shortlisted five candidates for the position
Her novel was shortlisted for the prestigious literary award
They shortlisted three companies for the construction contract
He was shortlisted for the scholarship among hundreds

definitions: carry something heavy on one's shoulders physically
push someone or something aside using one's shoulder
accept responsibility or blame for something difficult
examples: He shouldered the heavy backpack for the mountain trek
Workers shouldered wooden beams across the construction site
She shouldered her way through the crowded subway car
The player shouldered his opponent away from the ball
The manager shouldered the blame for the project's failure
She willingly shouldered responsibility for her team's mistakes

definitions: speak or call out in a very loud voice
attract someone's attention by calling out loudly to them
examples: The coach shouted instructions from the sidelines constantly
She had to shout over the loud music
He shouted her name across the crowded parking lot
The vendor shouted his prices to passing customers

definitions: push someone or something roughly and with sudden force
examples: He shoved his way through the crowd impatiently
Someone shoved me from behind on the platform
She shoved the papers into her bag hurriedly
The bully shoved the smaller kid against the wall

definitions: dig and move earth snow or other material with a shovel
move or put something somewhere quickly and carelessly
examples: He shoveled snow from the driveway all morning long
Workers shoveled dirt into the truck for hours
She shoveled food into her mouth between meetings
He quickly shoveled papers into his briefcase

definitions: make something visible or allow it to be seen
demonstrate or explain how something works or is done
guide or escort someone to a particular place
provide evidence or proof that reveals something to be true
examples: She showed her new paintings at the gallery
The x-ray showed a fracture in his ankle
Can you show me how to use this software?
The instructor showed the proper swimming technique
The waiter showed us to our table immediately
She showed him around the new office building
Studies show that exercise improves mental health significantly
His actions showed his true character clearly

definitions: wash oneself in a shower with running water
fall or descend in large quantities like rain
give someone many things or much of something generously
examples: She showers every morning before going to work
The athletes showered after the intense training session
Confetti showered down on the winning team
Sparks showered from the welding torch
Grandparents often shower their grandchildren with gifts
Critics showered praise on the breakthrough performance

definitions: tear or cut something into small strips or pieces
damage or destroy someone's reputation argument or credibility completely
examples: She shredded confidential documents before disposal
The machine shreds paper into tiny unreadable pieces
The prosecutor shredded the defendant's alibi in court
Critics shredded the new policy proposal mercilessly

definitions: utter a high-pitched piercing sound or cry from fear or excitement
examples: She shrieked when she saw the spider
Children shrieked with delight on the roller coaster
The brakes shrieked as the car came to a stop
Wind shrieked through the broken window all night

definitions: make a high-pitched piercing sound that is unpleasant to hear
examples: The alarm shrilled throughout the entire building continuously
Her voice shrilled with panic when she called
The whistle shrilled to signal the end of the game
Cicadas shrilled in the trees during summer evenings

definitions: become or make smaller in size or amount through contraction
move back or away from something unpleasant through fear
examples: Cotton shirts often shrink in hot water
The company's profits shrank by twenty percent
She shrank from his angry outburst instinctively
He shrank back against the wall in terror

definitions: cover or envelop something completely with cloth or material
obscure or conceal something in mystery or secrecy
examples: They shrouded the body in white linen cloth
Fog shrouded the mountain peaks all morning
The company shrouded its plans in complete secrecy
Mystery shrouds the ancient civilization's sudden disappearance

definitions: shake or tremble convulsively from fear disgust or cold
of machinery or structures shake or vibrate violently
examples: She shuddered at the thought of eating insects
He shuddered involuntarily in the freezing wind
The old engine shuddered before finally starting
The building shuddered during the earthquake

definitions: walk without lifting one's feet properly from the ground
mix playing cards by sliding them over each other
rearrange the order or position of things randomly
examples: The elderly man shuffled slowly down the hallway
She shuffled to the kitchen in her slippers
He shuffled the deck before dealing the cards
The dealer shuffled expertly with one hand
They shuffled the playlist to hear random songs
Management shuffled personnel between different departments

definitions: persistently avoid reject or ignore someone or something deliberately
examples: The community shunned him after the scandal broke
She shuns publicity and rarely gives interviews
Many investors shun risky ventures during economic downturns
He shunned his former friends after becoming famous

definitions: move a train or rail vehicle to a different track
move someone or something to a different less important place
examples: Workers shunted the freight cars onto the siding
The locomotive was shunted to the maintenance yard
They shunted difficult patients to other departments
The proposal was shunted aside for later consideration

definitions: move something to block an opening or close a door
cease business operations or stop functioning
examples: Please shut the door quietly when you leave
She shut her eyes tightly during the scary scene
The factory shut permanently due to financial losses
They shut the restaurant early on Sundays

definitions: close the shutters of a window or building
permanently close a business or cease operations
examples: Residents shuttered their windows before the hurricane
They shuttered the beach house for the winter
The company shuttered three factories this year
Many restaurants were shuttered during the pandemic

definitions: travel regularly between two or more places
transport people or things repeatedly between places
examples: She shuttles between New York and Boston weekly
Buses shuttle between the airport and downtown
The van shuttles workers to the factory each morning
Parents shuttle their children to various activities

definitions: of a horse suddenly move away in fright or alarm
throw or fling something at a target
examples: The horse shied at the sudden noise
She shied away from physical contact
Boys shied stones at the old fence
He shied the ball at the target

definitions: set a dog or other animal to attack someone
examples: The guard sicced his dog on the intruder
She threatened to sic her lawyers on them
He sicced the hunting dogs on the fleeing deer
Don't make me sic security on you

definitions: bring up food from the stomach through the mouth
examples: The rough seas made several passengers sick up
The dog sicked on the carpet last night
She felt like she might sick after the roller coaster
He sicked up his entire dinner

definitions: support or agree with one person or group against another
examples: She always sides with her brother in arguments
The judge sided with the plaintiff's interpretation
Most committee members sided against the proposal
He refused to side with either faction

definitions: remove a player from a game or someone from active participation
examples: The coach sidelined the injured player immediately
An injury sidelined her for six weeks
Budget cuts sidelined several important projects
They sidelined him from the negotiations

definitions: pass something through a sieve to separate fine from coarse particles
examples: She sieved the flour to remove any lumps
The chef sieved the sauce for a smooth texture
Archaeologists sieved the soil for small artifacts
Workers sieved sand to get uniform grain size

definitions: put a substance through a sieve to remove lumps
examine something thoroughly and carefully to find what is important
examples: She sifted flour into the mixing bowl
The baker sifted powdered sugar over the cake
Detectives sifted through evidence for hours
Researchers sifted the data for meaningful patterns

definitions: exhale audibly expressing sadness relief or tiredness
make a soft prolonged sound like wind
examples: She sighed deeply after hearing the bad news
He sighed with relief when the test ended
The wind sighed through the pine trees
The old house sighed and creaked at night

definitions: see or observe someone or something especially suddenly
take aim by looking through the sights of a weapon
examples: We sighted land after three days at sea
Bird watchers sighted a rare eagle yesterday
The sniper carefully sighted his target
She sighted the rifle at the distant target

definitions: write one's name on a document to authorize it
communicate using sign language or gestures
formally engage someone for employment or a contract
examples: Please sign your name at the bottom
She signed the contract without reading it
He signs fluently in American Sign Language
The teacher signed the instructions to deaf students
The team signed a new quarterback yesterday
She was signed by a major record label

definitions: transmit information or instructions by means of gesture or device
indicate one's intentions or give advance notice of action
examples: The referee signaled for a timeout
Ships signal their position with lights
She signaled her intention to change lanes
His resignation signals major changes ahead

definitions: be a sign or indication of something important
make known or express the meaning of something
examples: A red light signifies danger in most cultures
These symptoms signify a serious medical condition
She signified her approval with a nod
The ceremony signifies the transition to adulthood

definitions: provide an area with signposts showing directions
indicate something clearly as a guide or warning
examples: They signposted the hiking trail last summer
The city signposted all major tourist attractions
The report signposts potential problems ahead
Teachers should signpost important concepts clearly

definitions: cause someone or something to become silent or stop making noise
prevent someone from expressing their opinions or speaking out
examples: The teacher silenced the noisy classroom immediately
A gesture from the conductor silenced the orchestra
The government tried to silence opposition voices
They silenced critics with legal threats

definitions: show or display someone or something as a dark shape against light
examples: The trees were silhouetted against the sunset sky
The dancer was silhouetted behind the screen
Mountains silhouetted dramatically in the evening light
The figure silhouetted in the doorway looked threatening

definitions: print designs on fabric or paper using silk screen printing technique
examples: The artist silkscreened posters for the exhibition
They silkscreen t-shirts with custom designs
The company silkscreens logos on promotional items
She learned to silkscreen in art class

definitions: become filled or blocked with silt or sediment deposits
examples: The harbor gradually silted up over decades
Heavy rains silted the reservoir significantly
The river mouth silts rapidly during floods
Irrigation channels silt without regular maintenance

definitions: cover something with a thin layer of silver
become silver or gray in color especially with age
examples: The jeweler silvered the antique mirror frame
They silver glass to make decorative ornaments
His hair silvered gracefully as he aged
Moonlight silvered the surface of the lake

definitions: cook food gently just below boiling point with small bubbles
exist in a suppressed state likely to break out
examples: Let the soup simmer for twenty minutes
She simmered the sauce until it thickened
Anger simmered beneath his calm exterior
Tensions have been simmering for months

definitions: make something easier to understand or do by reducing complexity
examples: The teacher simplified the math problem for students
We need to simplify this complicated process
Technology has simplified many daily tasks considerably
They simplified the application form last year
